009package imagingbook.common.math.eigen;
010
011import static org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition.DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD;
012import static org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition.DEFAULT_RELATIVE_SYMMETRY_THRESHOLD;
013
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition;
015//import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition;
016import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.DecompositionSolver;
017import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.EigenDecomposition;
018import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.LUDecomposition;
019import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
020import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.NonPositiveDefiniteMatrixException;
021import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
022import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealVector;
023
024/**
025 * <p>
026 * Solves the generalized symmetric eigenproblem of the form A x = &lambda; B x,
027 * where matrices A, B are symmetric and B is positive definite (see Sec.
028 * 11.0.5. of [1]). See Appendix Sec. B.5.2 of [2] for more details. The methods
029 * defined by this class are analogous to the conventional eigendecomposition
030 * (see {@link EigenDecomposition}).
031 * </p>
032 * <p>
033 * [1] Press, Teukolsky, Vetterling, Flannery: "Numerical Recipes". Cambridge
034 * University Press, 3rd ed. (2007). <br>
035 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
036 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
037 * </p>
038 * 
039 * @see GeneralizedEigenDecomposition
040 * @see EigenDecompositionJama
041 * @author WB
042 * @version 2022/06/11
043 */
044public class GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition implements RealEigenDecomposition {
045        
046        private final EigenDecomposition eigendecompY;
047        private final DecompositionSolver solverLT;
048        
049        /**
050         * Constructor.
051         * An exception is thrown if A is not symmetric and
052         * the Cholesky decomposition throws an exception if B is either not symmetric,
053         * not positive definite or singular.
054         * 
055         * @param A real symmetric matrix
056         * @param B real symmetric and positive definite matrix
057         * @param rsth  relative symmetry threshold
058         * @param apth absolute positivity threshold
059         */
060        public GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition(RealMatrix A, RealMatrix B, double rsth, double apth) {
061                if (!MatrixUtils.isSymmetric(A, rsth)) {
062                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix A must be symmetric");
063                }
064                
065                if (!MatrixUtils.isSymmetric(B, rsth)) {
066                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix B must be symmetric");
067                }
068                
069                CholeskyDecomposition cd = null;
070                try {
071                        cd = new CholeskyDecomposition(B, rsth, apth);
072                } catch (NonPositiveDefiniteMatrixException e) {
073                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix B must be positive definite");
074                }
075
076                RealMatrix L = cd.getL();
077
078                // find Q, such that Q * LT = A or equivalently L * QT = AT = A (since A is symmetric)
079                DecompositionSolver sL = new LUDecomposition(L).getSolver();
080                RealMatrix Q = sL.solve(A);
081
082                // find Y, such that L * Y = QT
083                RealMatrix Y = sL.solve(Q.transpose());
084                
085                // Y has the same eigenvalues as the original system and eigenvectors v_k
086                this.eigendecompY = new EigenDecomposition(Y);  // use EigenDecompositionJama instead?
087                
088                // the eigenvectors x_k of the original system are related
089                // to the eigenvectors v_k of Y as x_k = (LT)^(-1) * v_k = (L^(-1))^T * v_k
090                // or found by solving L^T * x_k = y_k, using the following solver:
091                this.solverLT = new LUDecomposition(cd.getLT()).getSolver();
092        }
093        
094        /**
095         * Constructor.
096         * 
097         * @param A real symmetric matrix
098         * @param B real symmetric and positive definite matrix
099         */
100        public GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition(RealMatrix A, RealMatrix B) {
101                this(A, B, 
102                                DEFAULT_RELATIVE_SYMMETRY_THRESHOLD, 
103                                DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD);
104        }
105        
106        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
107        
108        @Override
109        public double[] getRealEigenvalues() {
110                return eigendecompY.getRealEigenvalues();
111        }
112        
113        @Override
114        public double getRealEigenvalue(int k) {
115                return eigendecompY.getRealEigenvalue(k);
116        }
117        
118        public double[] getImagEigenvalues() {
119                return eigendecompY.getImagEigenvalues();
120        }
121        
122        @Override
123        public boolean hasComplexEigenvalues() {
124                return eigendecompY.hasComplexEigenvalues();
125        }
126        
127        @Override
128        public RealMatrix getD() {
129                return eigendecompY.getD();
130        }
131        
132        @Override
133        public RealVector getEigenvector(int k) {
134//              return LiT.operate(ed.getEigenvector(k));
135                // solve LT * x_k = v_k
136                RealVector vk = eigendecompY.getEigenvector(k);
137                return solverLT.solve(vk);
138        }
139
140        @Override
141        public RealMatrix getV() {
142//              return LiT.multiply(ed.getV());
143                // solve LT * X = V
144                return solverLT.solve(eigendecompY.getV());
145        }
146
147        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
148
